most people think of devops team still

so working remotely has been huge huge

that you know they don't need to be

down to an office and have to deal with

just roll out of bed pop open a laptop
and be like all right let's get it fixed
um that's one of the key things I think
is when you think about devops the point

under that umbrella is basically the
concept of keeping things moving forward
uh in doing that you know especially
when it comes to sres you really need to

and having to drive and go into an

when you're remote you can continue to
be laser focused even though you know
you're dragged out of bed that makes
sense what is the future of devops
that's a complicated question um a lot

uh that's true to a degree uh I don't

there's lots of things that you can aut

in order to merge everyone's code at the

now with cicd everything kind of come

virtually so you can continue to develop

that's key I think the the the future of
devops is also realizing that some of
the direct concepts of devops are maybe
a little bit misleading or mistaken uh
and by that I mean the initial concept
of devops is any one person on a on a
product team building a product building
an application should be able to do
anything from A to Z from writing the
code to testing the code to deploying
the code to monitoring when it's out in
the world that's great in theory and in
a utopian world that would totally work
but well we don't need the silos that we
used to have where it was like I just
write code and then I toss it over the

over the wall to the to the
infrastructure team I don't think you
need that so much but what you do need
to do is realize that people can
only train different areas to a certain
degree um the idea of you know that was
once popular of like a 10x developer a
10x devops person is preposterous it's
ridiculous we shouldn't expect anyone to
do 10 times the work at any point in
time focus on your on your research area
focus on your work area make sure that's
working well overlap to learn what the
other teams do so that if they do need
your help you can step in but at no
point in time should we expect that
someone beginning to end knows every
single step of the process maybe they're
aware of every step of the process maybe
they can help with every step of the
process but they shouldn't be in control
of every step of the process I think
that's the key thing that a lot of
people miss with devops now now in the

things maybe that's not necessary maybe
we can have someone who just writes code
hits a button it's automatically QA
automatically deployed and there's
monitoring so that people can watch it
but I think that a lot of people also
hear automation they think oh we're

I don't think that's going to happen

of people it's a huge concern um and I
know a lot of people who are in the

well why are you doing this then that
seems crazy why why are you writing the

they realize that there has to be a
human factor we build software
applications for human beings we do not
build software applications for other
software yet I mean I don't know if that
far in the future will happen but if we
keep that in mind then we need to
realize there always needs to be a human
factor uh I think a great example of
this there was a little study done where

made up of a bunch of white guys so when
they put it out in the world they
realized that people who weren't white
guys didn't get picked up by the facial
recognition they couldn't figure out
what they had done wrong they were like
ah what do and that's that's kind of
where it comes at you know into play in
devops is like if you don't have a human
factor you're going to miss some key
piece of information that may or may not
get looked at correctly um you know
great another great example is with

biggest problem with that is nine times

you have to learn that um so that's
